text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday morning's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Neritan Ceka, the opposition Democratic Alliance party leader, urged the constitutional court to decide on a new law according to which members of local electoral commissions who boycott the polls while voting is still under way could be sentenced to up to three years in jail.
- A presidential decree entitles ministries to privatise enterprises and properties they direct, including the defence ministry privatising arms factories.
- Exports have not yet returned to the levels posted in 1989 because production in the Albanian economy remains small.
- Heavy rain disrupted traffic in the country.
- EU's PHARE program will offer financing of $500,000 for the construction of waste disposal sites in the south-western city of Vlore.
- Organisers put the finishing touches to the Miss Europe '96 beauty show to be held on Saturday.
- Albanian immigrants in Sweden start a hunger strike to protest against their return to former Yugoslavia.
- A German frigate arrived in the port city of Durres to prepare for joint military exercises with Albania next month.
- Tritan Shehu, deputy prime minister and foreign minister, met his Austrian, Bulgarian and Portuguese counterparts in the annual U.N. General Assembly in New York.

- Central Electoral Commission said the participation of President Sali Berisha and of the other officials in the Democrats' campaign was constitutional, contradicting the opposition Socialists' charge.
- Italian embassy in Tirana denies press reports that some 500 Italian observers will monitor the October 20 local elections.
- Europe and the U.S. have spent some five million dollars on training Albanian students over the last few years.
